data.name: Geneva Mont Blanc Wine Tour
data.abstract: A bike tour of the vineyards above Geneva.
data.description: The Geneva countryside invites you to take a bike ride and taste some fine wines. Treat yourself to an invigorating excursion on an electric bike just a stone’s throw from the city centre. Then make a stopover at a vineyard and try a glass of delicious home-grown wine. Sports enthusiasts, gourmands and nature lovers will surely be impressed.

data.name: Geneva City Tour
data.abstract: Discover Geneva on this bus tour as you visit "International Geneva", Geneva’s main tourist attractions and the Old Town.
data.description:
Discover Geneva in all its aspects on this bus tour. In "International Geneva" you will be introduced to the organisations working for world peace before visiting such major tourist attractions as the famous Jet d'Eau and the beautiful Flower Clock. 
Finally, go back in time aboard the mini-train Tramway Tour of the Old Town and accompany your guide for a close up visit to the alleys of the Old Town. 
City Tour [https://www.geneve.com/en/object/city-tour-47.product/]

data.name: Geneva Wine Trail
data.abstract: The longest vineyard walk in Switzerland. Discover the magnificent Geneva countryside by following three fascinating didactic itineraries combining wine growing, nature and local products.
data.description:
The vineyard walk criss-crosses Geneva, Switzerland’s third-largest wine producer. The three itineraries are equipped with information panels introducing Geneva’s grape varieties. The Rive Droite (right bank of the Rhône) itinerary passes through Switzerland's largest wine growing village, Satigny. From there, you will enjoy an exceptional view of Mont-Salève. The Entre Arve et Rhône walk introduces the “Champagne” region where a great many restaurants propose local products. Last but not least, the Entre Arve et Lac walk follows the left bank of the Rhône through charming historic villages.
Rive Droite Itinerary [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/route/rive-droite/]
25.9 km – 6h 10 min. of walking 
Meyrin – La Plaine – Meyrin 

Entre Arve et Rhône Itinerary [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/route/entre-arve-et-rhone/]
26.5 km – 6h 40 min. of walking 
La Plaine – Croix de Rozon 

Entre Arve et Lac Itinerary [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/route/entre-arve-et-lac/]
18.9 km – 4h 30 min. of walking 
Hermance - Choulex

data.name: Geneva Mystery
data.abstract: A gripping investigation that leads you through the heart of Geneva’s historic centre. Love suspense? Then immerse yourself in the Geneva Mystery to find Professor Archibald Kymerion and discover the reason for his mysterious disappearance on an evening in June 1893.
data.description: Geneva Mystery is a thrilling game of enigmas that lets you discover Geneva in an original way, on your own, with family or with friends. Use your powers of deduction and observation to progress the investigation at your own pace. But don’t delay too long, or you could fail! A mix of history and fiction, the case takes you to the historic and iconic places of the Old Town such as St. Peter’s Cathedral, the archaeological site and the International Museum of the Reformation. A formidable game of intrigue in an exceptional setting.

data.name: Geneva Wine Cellar
data.abstract: For several years Geneva has boldly diversified its grape varieties. Today La Cave de Genève produces fifteen varieties.
data.description:
Gamaret, Cabernet Franc, Merlot, Garanoir, Cabernet Sauvignon, Pinot Noir, Gamay are the red wines; Sauvignon Blanc, Sauvignon Gris, Viognier, Chardonnay, Pinot Blanc, RieslingxSylvaner, Chasselas and Muscat represent the white wines.
Thanks to the vineyards, which extend over 400 hectares and belong to 100 vintners, La Cave de Genève produces 25% of the Canton of Geneva’s potential. 

A visit to a wine cellar and the production center is definitely worth your while. You will have the opportunity to taste wines from a large assortment. 


Open: Monday to Friday 

Sale at the Reception Desk: 8 a.m. to 12 p.m. / 1:30 p.m. to 5 p.m. 

Reservation requested for groups of 10 or more.

data.name: Geneva Watch Tour
data.abstract: The Geneva Watch Tour through the Old Town offers an entertaining journey through the realm of watchmaking.
data.description:
This is just a short walk, but it takes you to the heart of the wonderful world of luxury watches. Along the way, it leads past 100-odd specialist shops as well as a dozen historic monuments, providing a fascinating insight into this traditional local industry. Highlights include the Patek Philippe Museum in the Plainpalais district, home to a priceless collection of antique watches from the 16th to 19th centuries as well as timepieces created by Patek Philippe since its foundation in 1839. The museum also houses a library dedicated to horology. 
www.genevawatchtour.com [http://www.genevawatchtour.com]

data.name: Carouge - Geneva
data.abstract: Carouge, just a few minutes from the center of Geneva, combines Sardinian architecture with creative flair. Boutiques, studios and cozy cafés characterize the district, while historic squares such as the Place du Marché and the River Arve create a special atmosphere.
data.description:
Just a few minutes from the center of Geneva is Carouge, a district with a Mediterranean flair and rich history. Once founded by the Sardinians, Carouge today delights with its charming squares, unique boutiques and lively markets. The district is a popular retreat for locals and visitors alike, who enjoy the creative ambience and relaxed atmosphere.

Carouge is known for its multitude of craft stores, studios and small galleries. Along the Rue Saint-Joseph, visitors will find handmade jewelry, original clothing and much more. The cozy street cafés and restaurants invite you to stop for a bite to eat.

The Sardinian architecture gives Carouge its special character. Highlights such as the Place du Marché and the Église Sainte-Croix provide an insight into the district's past. A visit is rounded off with a walk along the River Arve, which separates Carouge from Geneva city center.

data.name: Lake Geneva Cruises
data.abstract: Boat cruising on Central Europe’s largest inland lake every which way. Passengers can embark and disembark on the Swiss as well as the French side of the lake.
data.description:
The Belle Époque boats have been navigating Central Europe’s largest inland lake for 140 years and offer fantastic cruises between France and Switzerland.

The views from the boat extend from harbours and castles (Chillon, Morges, Rolle, Yvoire among others) over vineyards (Lavaux UNESCO and La Côte) to the snow-covered summits of the Swiss and Savoyan Alps. The boat landings are starting points for many exploration activities like city tours (Geneva, Lausanne, Montreux, Vevey).FACTS

Route: e.g. Geneva – Nyon – Lausanne
Distance: Length of the lake 72 km
Duration: 3 h 45 min

EXCURSION TIPS
 * The Olympic Museum [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/the-olympic-museum/] in Lausanne
 * The Notre-Dame Cathedral [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/notre-dame-cathedral/] of Lausanne
 * Chaplin's World [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/chaplins-world/] in Corsier-sur-Vevey
 * The Cheese Train [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/cheese-train/] starting in Montreux

FOOD & BEVERAGES

Catering services available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE

Ticket
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]


Reservations
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Touring Geneva’s vineyards
data.abstract: Geneva’s best-kept secret lies outside the city: its 1,500 hectares of sunny vineyards, which produce some of the country’s finest wines.
data.description: A particularly pleasant way to explore this charming region overlooking Lake Geneva is by bike. Hire is free of charge for up to four hours – with the added advantage that you’ll be able to taste the odd glass along the way, at one of the country restaurants that match the wines with local delicacies.

data.name: Paragliding over Geneva
data.abstract: Lay the parachute out ready, run and jump – soar high over Geneva and enjoy glorious views of the city, lake and Alps.
data.description:
Flights are offered daily by the paragliding school in Geneva from mid-June to the start of September. Comfort and safety are guaranteed by the professional guide. The flight over Geneva begins on Mont Salève, from where the courageous will take off together with an experienced pilot and soar into the skies over Geneva. 

Those who would like to learn how to fly by themselves can book a one-day course. During this, you will learn more about the equipment, steering technique and how to take control on a tandem flight.More information [https://www.geneve.com/en/attractions/paragliding-school-in-geneva-paradelta-ch/]

data.abstract: Geneva, Jet d'Eau, Flower Clock and then what? Discover all the secrets of the city with guides from Geneva Tourism!
data.description:
Discover the Old Town of Geneva, Switzerland’s largest historical city. 
Accompanied by a professional guide, listen to amazing stories about the St. Pierre Cathedral, the Town Hall or l'Ancien Arsenal, and all the secrets of the city of the Reformation.

data.name: Old Town of Geneva
data.abstract: Geneva's old town, also known as the “Vieille Ville”, is the historic center of the city and invites you to take a trip back in time.
data.description:
Characterized by narrow alleyways, charming squares and centuries-old buildings, every corner tells the story of Geneva's eventful history. The Place du Bourg-de-Four, the oldest square in the city, is an ideal starting point for exploring. Visitors will find cozy cafés, restaurants and small boutiques here. An absolute highlight is the Cathédrale Saint-Pierre, which offers breathtaking views of the city with its impressive architecture and the opportunity to climb the tower.


There are numerous museums and cultural attractions in the old town. The Maison Tavel, the oldest house in Geneva, houses a museum on the city's history, while the Musée de l'Art et d'Histoire delights art and culture lovers with its extensive collections. The Rue du Rhône, just a few steps away, combines the historic flair of the old town with modern shopping opportunities. For a relaxing break, head to the Parc des Bastions, where the impressive Reformation Monument commemorates Geneva's role during the Reformation. Geneva's old town is a must for anyone who wants to combine culture, history and relaxation.

data.name: Reformation Walking Tour Geneva
data.abstract: A self-guided walking tour allows visitors to tour Geneva's Reformation highlights at their own pace.
data.description: The route takes visitors past the Museum of the Reformation, St. Peter's Cathedral, Calvin's Auditorium, the Reformation Monument and Calvin College. Copies of the guide are available at the Museum of the Reformation.

data.name: Bains des Pâquis – The Geneva way of life
data.abstract: Enjoy a fondue on the lake.
data.description:
In winter guests relax in the sauna with a wonderful view of the lake. Fondue aficionados come here to enjoy their cheese speciality while admiring Geneva’s sea of lights reflected in the water. The hamam and Turkish bath offer relaxation all year round. 

The Bains des Pâquis cultural meeting point offers a wide range of activities. It’s much more than purely a swimming pool and has really become a must-visit venue when staying in Geneva.

data.name: Trains & Trolleys Tours in Geneva
data.abstract: Discover Geneva and her main attractions with 3 sightseeing tours: «Parks and Residences Tour», «International Tour» and «Old Town Tour».
data.description:
The «Parks and Residences» mini-train will take you on a dream journey along the right bank of Lake Geneva to discover beautiful parks and gardens. 

The Trolley «International Tour» will make you understand the international dimension of Geneva by leading you to the meeting of the buildings of the UN and the International Organizations which work for the good of humanity and peace in the world. 

The Tramway «Old Town of Geneva» invites you back to the past.Through its narrow streets and alleyways you will discover the old town and its 2000 years of closely guarded history. 
More information: Trains & Trolley Tours Geneva [http://www.trains-tours.ch/]

data.name: Boat fishing on lake Geneva
data.abstract: Fishing boat trips on lake Geneva, with experienced and pleasant pilot/fishing guide, speaking french and english. Fishing of pike, white fish, perch, char, or lake trout, depending on the season.
data.description: Open to beginners and experiencedanglers, children and youngsters welcome. All the necessaryfishing equipement, as well as lures and bait, are provided, included in the rates. Small fishing rods for children are also provided. All boats are equiped with electronic fishfinders. HD video can be utilized for fishing trip souvenir films. Choice of boats of different sizes available, up to twelvepassengers. Optional possibility to have picnic baskets delivedon the boat, or lunch reservations at lakeside restaurants withmooring pontoon.

data.name: Fishing trip on Lake Geneva
data.abstract: From mid-January to the end of November, angling enthusiasts can rent a boat for private fishing trips and, with a little luck, catch arctic char, perch, zander, pike or brown trout.
data.description:
In Geneva and Nyon, boats can be hired for one to six passengers for a minimum of two hours. Fishing equipment is included in the boat hire. Once everything and everyone is aboard, nothing stands in the way of a fun fishing trip on the largest freshwater lake in Europe, Lake Geneva

More information [https://www.geneve.com/en/attractions/boat-fishing-trip/]

data.name: Gourmet cruises on Lake Geneva
data.abstract: Gourmet cruises on Lake Geneva
data.description:
On a paddle steamer from the Belle Époque, enjoy a delicate dish of the day or a gourmet lunch or dinner menu, while gazing at the Lake Geneva landscape as it glides by. 
During the summer months, our catering partner will be pleased to offer a varied choice of dishes on one of our historic Belle Epoque boats. 
From September till March special fondue cruises sail every Friday. 

An excursion that is both relaxing and invigorating at any time of year.

data.name: Auditoire de Calvin (Calvin's Auditorium) Geneva
data.abstract: Originally built as the Notre-Dame-la-Neuve chapel, the 15th-century Auditorium became a lecture hall at the time of the Reformation (1536).
data.description: On this site Calvin taught Reformed theology, and numerous Protestant refugee groups worshiped in their own tongue, including Italian Waldensians, the Dutch Reformed and the Scottish Presbyterians. (These groups continue to worship in the auditorium every weekend.) The Auditorium's most famous preacher after Calvin was John Knox, who carried Protestant theology to his native Scotland. A memorial to the French Reformers sits on the left side of the nave.

data.name: E-bike tour in the Geneva vineyards
data.abstract: Discover the wonderful vineyards of Geneva on a comfortable e-bike tour. Naturally a winetasting is included.
data.description: Visitors can explore the world of wine on a guided e-bike tour in the nearby Geneva vineyards. Of course, the tour also includes a chance to sample different wines. But the tour is not just a memorable experience for connoisseurs. Sports enthusiasts and nature lovers alike will also enjoy the outing. The tour is led by a professional guide whose passion for the Geneva regions has many surprises in store.

data.name: Guided tour: The flavours of Geneva chocolate
data.abstract: On this guided tour, the experts from “Geneva Food Tour” present a selection of award-winning Geneva chocolate creations.
data.description:
Truffles, chocolates, the traditional Geneva chocolate kettle or an award-winning chocolate cake: this tour allows you to discover the best chocolatiers of the city and a total of eleven sweet creations.

Over a period of three hours, you can try local varieties and explore every aspect of the Geneva chocolate world. The tour includes five chocolate manufacturers and confectioners – including one that has supplied Winston Churchill, Grace Kelly, J.F. Kennedy and Charles de Gaulles with chocolate delicacies.

The tour is led by a passionate guide who introduces guests to all the secrets about Geneva chocolate. The itinerary also includes a boat tour and a stroll through Geneva’s old town.

Local Flavours Tour [https://www.localflavourstours.com]

data.name: Terrace bars with a view of Lake Geneva
data.abstract: What could be nicer than rounding off a warm summer evening in one of Lausanne’s terrace bars? There are plenty of trendy bars to choose from in this town on the shores of Lake Geneva.
data.description: Whether you’re looking for something cosy, secluded or modern: Lausanne’s terrace bars have it all to offer. Thanks to the city’s hilltop vantage point there are views of Lake Geneva almost everywhere you go. There are terrace bars in the city centre as well as nearer by. The customer is king. The choice is vast. There is something for everyone here. Whether accompanied by a delicious meal or a glass of wine, a summer evening on the terrace with a panoramic view of Lake Geneva will never be forgotten.

data.name: A beach right in the heart of Geneva
data.abstract: It’s finally time to head to the beach in Geneva! Eaux-Vives Beach raises the bar, with superb views of the Jet d’Eau water fountain and its new “Anneau Aquatique” ring-shaped platform right over the water, which is a lovely spot to relax.
data.description:
EAUX-VIVES PUBLIC BEACH
Swimming right in the heart of the city has always been popular with locals and tourists alike. And now they have another place to do just that, with the new Eaux-Vives Public Beach, which also makes you feel like you’re on a lakeside holiday. It features a long, wide sandy beach, with a number of pebble sections. In addition, the leafy park connected to the beach is a perfect place to unwind. What’s more, visitors will be able to enjoy street food and ice creams served from the electric tricycles operating along the beach front.
THE “ANNEAU AQUATIQUE” 
This incredible sunbathing area has been built near to the Tour Carrée, just a stone’s throw from the city centre. Sunbathers can have fun while enjoying the lake on this ring-shaped structure over the water, which measures 40 metres in diameter. This circular platform was built out of concrete, which has been covered in wood, and boasts a sort of lakeside pool in the middle.

For more information: Eaux-Vives Public Beach [https://www.geneve.com/en/attractions/eaux-vives-beach]

New for 2021: Restaurant de la Plage [https://restoplage.ch/]

data.name: Montreux Ice Rink - skating on the shores of Lake Geneva
data.abstract: This 300 m2 ice rink in the Montreux market hall may be used free of charge and is open from early January to mid-April.
data.description:
The ice rink is completely independent of temperature since it is made of synthetic materials, but still provides the feeling of being on real ice. Hence it may be used with the conventional materials and techniques. 

The ice rink is located in the market hall in the heart of Montreux. This historic, late 19th century lakeside architectural monument affords skaters a panoramic view of the Alps and Lake Geneva.

data.name: Across the vineyards by train
data.abstract: The “Train des vignes” (vineyard train) runs on a fantastic route through the terraced vineyards of Lavaux, the landscape high above Lake Geneva designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2007, with views of the Savoy and Valais Alps.
data.description:
An hourly regional train from Vevey station to Puidoux-Chexbres offers the unusual experience of travelling across the terraced vineyards of the Lavaux UNESCO World Heritage Site. From Chexbres-Village station, where the train stops along the way, there are many footpaths through the magnificent, steep terraces. A signposted educational trail tells the story of the vineyard and the grape varieties grown there. 

The “Lavaux Panoramic” is a tourist train with tyred wheels that carries visitors from Chexbres-Village along narrow roads through the vineyards. On the way, travellers can learn about the characteristics of the region as they admire the spectacular landscape. Similar trains known as the “Lavaux Express” also run through the Lavaux vineyards from Lutry and Cully. The winegrowers offer tourists the chance to taste their wines in their cellars.

data.name: ViaJacobi - Fascinating route to spiritual salvation
data.abstract: Route: Konstanz (D)/Rorschach - Einsiedeln - Willisau/Brienz - Freiburg - Payerne/Romont-Lausanne - Geneva
data.description: The pilgrimage to the shrine of Saint James in Santiago de Compostela (northern Spain) is one of the most important spiritual traditions in Europe. As part of the European Way of St. James, the ViaJacobi passes along the foot of the Alps from Lake Constance to Geneva – right through the heart of Switzerland. Like pearls on a chain, chapels, churches and hostels are lined up one after the other along the ViaJacobi and, together with the cultural landscape that is crammed with variety, make for a fantastic hiking experience.

data.name: Genève GE
data.abstract: A stroll through Geneva can be easily combined with bird watching.
data.description:
Geneva’s Harbor Bay, especially the Pâquis-Dam, is well suited for watching the birds during their migration period in autumn, but also for observing the feathered winter guests. 

Picture: Caspian Gull

data.name: Down by the riverside
data.abstract: A new, natural look for the city: a fascinating riverscape opens up by the Sous-Terre bridge, in the heart of Geneva.
data.description:
After its turbulent descent from the glacier in which it was born and after which it is named, the Rhone lingers a few moments in Lake Geneva before tackling its long and leisurely descent to the sea. As it slowly flows past Geneva, it creates a haven where peace and discovery are the main attractions. 
Going down the Rhone by boat, canoe or kayak is a wonderful experience as you share moments of quiet tranquility with family or friends. Gently borne along by the current, you will discover the hidden treasures of its banks.

data.name: Métro Lausanne – true underground rail
data.abstract: Every couple of minutes, a train from Lausanne-Ouchy by Lake Geneva runs almost silently uphill to the SBB railway station and onwards via the city centre (Flon) to Epalinges-Croisettes. The fully automated Métro trains are remotely controlled and spend half their time underground.
data.description:
Stand at the front of the Métro and it feels like you're driving the train yourself. 

The line almost six kilometres long covers a bigger altitude difference than any other underground railway – 336 metres, with a maximum gradient of 12%. In the coming years, another line is planned from Blécherette via Palais de Beaulieu to Flon and onwards to a new terminus in the SBB railway station. 

Once comprising two funicular railways known as “La Ficelle” (the string), then converted to cog railways and now run on solid rubber wheels much like the Paris Métro, the Lausanne city railway has an interesting history of development that began way back in 1877. The Ouchy-Flon funicular railway was the very first in Switzerland, while the parallel line from the Lausanne SBB station to Flon was the world's first cableway. The ropeway carriages were also once used to push ordinary rail freight wagons.
Altitude: 719m 
Accessibility: 
Métro in Lausanne’s SBB railway station, boat in Ouchy, bus connection to and from Epalinges-Croisettes 
View: Over Ouchy and Lake Geneva as far as the French Savoyer and Vaud Alps 
Attractions: Sitting up-front in the Métro, as if driving it yourself 
Culinary aspects: Culinary highlights in Lausanne’s Old Town between the station and Flon 
Overnight stays: In Lausanne’s city center and Ouchy am See 
Winter: Year-round operations 
Special comments: Planned extension project as far as Blécherette (M3)

data.name: Le Baroque
data.abstract: Le Baroque is a legendary club in Geneva with an intimate ambiance due to its limited space. A glamorous setting with a select clientele.
data.description:
Here, Parisian luxury is implanted in Geneva. Le Baroque. A name, a whole world, and so authentic. 
This nightclub, at the Place de la Fusterie 12, opened its doors in 1993. The Baroque Club has made its mark on the scene with its unique character. The atmosphere, ambiance and liveliness make it one of the leading addresses and much more than just a nightclub. 
This is a place where two worlds, that of musical culture and that of artistic culture, unite to our delight.

data.name: Golf in the Valais region
data.abstract: Set between the Rhone Glacier and Lake Geneva and boasting 47 mighty 4000-meter-high peaks, Valais pledges guests a truly unique golfing experience.
data.description:
The eight golf clubs in Valais offer variety-packed golf in stunningly beautiful surroundings whether in the mountains or flatlands. Magnificent alpine decor, pristine nature, superb wines and traditional dishes along with hours of sunshine lure guests here, which is not surprising is it!GOLF COURSES

data.name: Bains de Cressy
data.abstract: In a world that is becoming increasingly stressful, the wellness and fitness areas of the Bains de Cressy – which can be found a little outside Geneva – offer plenty of peace and relaxation.
data.description:
Under a large glass ceiling, surrounded by an array of tropical plants, you can relax in the 34°C water or in one of the jacuzzis. Enjoy the revitalising powers of the sauna, hammam or odorium (aroma inhalation bath).

Recharge your batteries and enjoy the beneficial effects of spa treatments and massages. 

Curative spa treatments: water massages, seaweed baths. 
Wellness massage treatments: reflexology, Shiatsu, Reiki, Thai, anti-cellulite treatments, hot stones, Thui Na.

Getting there: By bus no. 21 to “Edouard-Vallet, bus no. 43 to “Bains de Cressy” or by car (parking in the basement).

data.name: Vevey lake promenade
data.abstract: The lakeside promenade in Vevey on Lake Geneva combines beautiful nature with culture. Stroll along flowering gardens, marvel at the famous fork sculpture in the water and visit the Charlie Chaplin statue.
data.description:
The lakeside promenade in Vevey is one of the most beautiful lakeside promenades on Lake Geneva (Lac Léman) and offers fantastic views of the lake and the Alps.

Along the promenade you will find flowering gardens and numerous works of art. A particular highlight is the iconic fork sculpture that rises out of the water and stands directly in front of the Alimentarium. This lakeside promenade is perfect for relaxing strolls while enjoying the picturesque landscape around Vevey.

Another popular photo motif is the Charlie Chaplin statue, which also stands on the lakeside promenade and commemorates the world-famous actor who lived in the region for many years. The combination of nature, art and history makes Vevey's lakeside promenade an ideal destination for tourists and locals alike.

image.name: Grand Train Tour of Switzerland Vevey

data.name: Chauderon Gorge
data.abstract: The natural wilderness is just a few steps away from the old town of Montreux. The La Baye de Montreux River flows through the gorge from the foot of Rochers-de-Naye into Lake Geneva.
data.description:
The entrance to Chauderon Gorge is just a short walk from the Montreux train station. As soon as you enter, you will forget the city entirely. The scent of wild garlic pervades the air as you follow the trail across both banks while listening to the burbling and gurgling of the Baye de Montreux River. The gorge, which is narrow at the beginning with some areas that are reminiscent of a rain forest, gradually opens up the farther up you go to Les Avant.

If you would like to keep on going, then you can continue on the Sentier des Narcisses trail. a signposted walking trail that passes along meadows, forests and viewing points overlooking Lake Geneva and the Alps. May carpets the path in narcissus blooms and fills the air with their perfume, while the green meadows are covered in a white blanket of May Snow creeping phlox. This rare spectacle attracts numerous visitors every year to the hills of the breathtakingly beautiful Montreux Riviera.

Getting there: By public transport or car to Montreux.

data.name: Maison Rousseau et Littérature (MRL)
data.abstract: A vivid introduction to give new insights into the legacy of one of Geneva’s most famous citizens, Jean-Jacques Rousseau.
data.description:
The legacy of the Enlightenment and contemporary literature

Maison Rousseau et Littérature, which is housed at the birthplace of Jean-Jacques Rousseau in Geneva’s old town, is an impressive six-storey building. Interest in the literature of French-speaking Switzerland, francophone countries and the whole world cried out to be addressed. Visitors can confront current affairs and the big issues of our time in the context of Rousseau’s work in all its modernity. The intention is that this unique venue should bring together writers, translators, readers of every age and background, schoolchildren, students, artists and thinkers in common dialogue.

An audio-visual tour allows visitors to immerse themselves in the life and work of Jean-Jacques Rousseau. The 25-minute tour, which is available in eight languages plus a version for young people, conveys the unique career of the famous ‘burgher of Geneva’, who was a philosopher, writer, musician and botanist.

As the leading literary institution in western Switzerland, the MRL regularly organises literary symposiums and debates to consider Rousseau’s work or to hear from contemporary writers.

To organise a tour, please contact christina.klotz@m-r-l.ch.
More information [https://m-r-l.ch/]

data.name: Glérolles Castle
data.abstract: The chateau stands on the shores of Lake Geneva in the heart of Lavaux and played an important role in the history of the canton of Vaud. It is also a winery that is allowed to carry the “Saint-Saphorin” designation of origin.
data.description:
The name of the chateau can be traced back to the Roman village of Glerula, which was probably destroyed by a tsunami in Lake Geneva in 563.
The first stones of the castle were laid in the 11th century. A first tower was constructed in 1150, before the main part of the castle was built from 1300 onwards.

These days, Glérolles Castle operates both as a winery and as a venue for events. The “Salle des Chevaliers” (Knights’ Hall) with its garden and covered terrace can be hired for private events.

Grapes of the varieties Chasselas, Pinot Noir, Humagne Rouge, Merlot, Cabernet Franc, Syrah and Gewürztraminer are grown on an area measuring almost five hectares at the Glérolles chateau vineyard. Legend has it that the watchtower had to be lowered in the 19th century because of the shadow it cast on the surrounding vines.

data.name: Russian orthodox church
data.abstract: The Russian orthodox church in Geneva is a genuine masterpiece of Byzantine-Muscovite style. This church was built thanks to the financial support of Geneva’s Russian orthodox community. Its sublime golden cupolas are a beacon that shines high over the city
data.description: In 1859 the Russian orthodox community in Geneva was granted permission to build this church, with financial assistance from Anna Feodorovna Constancia, sister-in-law of Tsar Alexander 1st. Dostoyevsky baptised his daughter Sophie here; she died at three months of age and is buried in the cemetery at Plainpalais. Situated above the Quartier des Eaux-Vives, the Russian church is built on the site of a former Benedictine priory. Its architecture is a masterpiece of Byzantine-Muscovite style and its golden cupolas, restored in 1966, are a magnificent landmark that can be seen from many miles distant.

data.name: Les Bastions Ice Rink
data.abstract: Skating in the heart of Geneva. Parc des Bastions has an ice rink that is perfect for couples, children and families alike – in other words: anyone who loves the thrill of skating on ice. What’s more, it’s free!
data.description:
Located just below Geneva’s old town, Parc des Bastions is like a set of green lungs right in the centre of the city. The area is very popular with walkers. For a number of years now a seasonal ice rink has been set up here every autumn and winter, bringing the thrill of skating to the heart of Geneva.

More information [https://www.geneve.com/de/attraktionen/die-eisbahn-les-bastions/]

price.description: Free admission Skate hire CHF 2 Skating aids are available for children and less experienced skaters.

data.name: Grand Théâtre
data.abstract: The Geneva Opera House, known and loved throughout the world. A magnificent theatre, inspired by the Palais Garnier in Paris and with a fabulous programme of events to suit even the most demanding of music lovers.
data.description: The Grand Théâtre de Genève is both a venue and an institution. The largest production theatre in French-speaking Switzerland, it hosts an annual season of operas, ballets and recitals with an international flavour. It seats 1500.

data.name: Town Hall Ramp
data.abstract: For over 500 years, the Town Hall has played a central role both in Geneva and internationally. This masterpiece of fifteenth-century architecture is equipped with a large and unique access ramp.
data.description: Located in the centre of the Old Town, the Town Hall is the political heart of the city and the seat of government for the Canton of Geneva. This building houses the famous Alabama Room in which the first Geneva Convention was adopted in 1864, from which was to emerge the International Red Cross. The large paved ramp surrounding the building its most unique feature. Built between 1555 and 1578 by Peter Desfosses, the design of the ramp enabled direct access to the upper floors on horseback or on foot.

data.name: River Rafting on the Arve
data.abstract: Enjoy an action-packed outdoor adventure in the city. This special three-hour rafting trip covers eight kilometres and includes six waterfalls, offering a chance to discover Geneva's surroundings in a completely different way.
data.description:
The River Arve rises at Mont Blanc, crosses the Savoy Alps and flows into the Rhone after more than 100km at “La Jonction”, a district on the edge of Geneva's city centre. The adventure begins by the Pont de Sierne bridge in Le Veyrier. As you pass through a succession of calm and rapid waters between the tree-lined banks, you'll barely notice the bustle of the city. 

The Arve is quite easy to navigate, so the trip is also suitable for beginners. This “whitewater adventure” in the city ends at the Quai des Vernets or shortly before the confluence of the Arve and Rhone.

data.name: Jura Paragliding
data.abstract: Along the entire Jura, right up to Geneva, the foothills of Freiburg, Saleve
data.description:
The Jura stretches from Basle to Geneva. Perfect for hang-gliding and thermals! With a recognised licence, nothing stands in the way of enjoyable, carefree flying. Without such a licence, you can still be whisked away into the skies by one of our SHV tandem pilots and see the full beauty of the Jura unfolding beneath you.

data.name: Vevey Excursion
data.abstract: Set on the beautiful shores of Lake Geneva, Vevey offers travelers the best of both worlds: A storybook perfect Swiss lake town, and very few tourists. Shop, sample the best goodies from the town's patisseries and boulangeries, and enjoy a cruise on Lake Geneva.
data.description: Nearby, in the tiny town of La Tour-de-Peilz, the Hostellerie Bon Rivage is a charming hotel and restaurant worth visiting. Once a convent for the Order of St. Joseph, the inn's dining room serves fish freshly caught from the adjoining lake and herbs and vegetables harvested from the property's garden.

data.name: ViaRomana - Myth and reality of the Roman roads
data.abstract: Route: Geneva - Lausanne - Orbe - Avenches - Solothurn - Augst
data.description:
Almost two-thousand years after its prime the fascination of Roman building techniques and culture lives on. Thanks to new excavations and research it has become much easier to separate myth from reality. Along idyllic Roman roads, real and imagined, the ViaRomana links the most important Roman sites in Switzerland. It spells out the Roman culture with all its facets. 

In eleven legs accomplished in eleven days, the ViaRomana path leads from Geneva to Augst via the Three-Lakes region. And between Avenches and Augst you get to see genuine Roman roads (Grosse Moos arch) as well as tracks from the early New Age, long thought to be Roman (St. Wolfgang, Oberer Hauenstein).

data.name: Exploring Morges by Small Train
data.abstract: Had enough of walking? Hop on board of the small train and explore Morges, jewel of Lake Geneva.
data.description:
The tour leaves from the TCS campsite in the Petit Bois and ends at the Parc de Vertou, travelling alongside the lake and crossing the Grand'Rue and the Parc de l'Indépendance. The journey lasts approximately forty minutes and will enthral children and adults alike! 
Tickets are sold on boarding the train.

How to get there:
By car: take the motorway in the direction of Geneva, exit at Morges-est and follow the signs for the centre until you reach the lake.
By public transport: take the Swiss Railways train to Morges.

data.name: Jet d'Eau
data.abstract: In Geneva harbour, known as “La Rade”, this water jet up to 140 m/460 ft high is a real eye-catcher. When you're in the area, don't miss the chance to have your photo taken with the fountain in the background... or shoot a selfie and send it there and then!
data.description:
As early as 1891, a decision was made to increase the height of the “Jet d'Eau” - originally constructed as a relief valve for the pipes supplying pressurised water to the jewellers' machinery – and illuminate it. Now a landmark of the city, it shoots 500 litres of lake water into the air every second at a speed of almost 200km/h. The airborne water in the permanent jet weighs more than five tons. 

The Jet d'Eau is best viewed from the Bains des Pâquis, a popular swimming venue for the locals. In winter, they all meet here for a sauna before the obligatory fondue.

data.name: Pont et Tour de l’Ile
data.abstract: Le Pont de l’Ile is what made Geneva a major crossroads for European trade. The history of this strategic site confirms that Geneva, often coveted by is neighbours over the centuries, was always set apart by its tenacity.
data.description: Opposite the Place Bel-Air is a little island on the Rhône. For many years this was the only checkpoint on the route linking northern and southern Europe, thanks to its bridge that spanned the two river banks. The commemorative plaque tells us that Julius Caesar had this bridge destroyed in 58 BC, which is when Geneva enters into the history books. Following its reconstruction, the city became a major European trade centre. In the 13th century a fortified castle was built here, of which only the tower now remains. The nearby Brasserie des Halles de l’Ile is the perfect spot to take a break!

data.name: Visit of the Swiss radio television studio
data.abstract: Every year almost 10'000 people discover the backstage of the Swiss Radio Television. If you too wish to understand how the Swiss media is working then book a visit of the radio in Lausanne or the television in Geneva.
data.description: The visits are organised in Lausanne and Geneva and last for approximately 1h30. Each visit is supervised by a guide and cost 100CHF for groups up to 20 people. On demande, the studio can welcome bigger groups, an extra guide will be added for every 20 people. The studios are enabling access by wheelchairs.

data.name: Quays of Montreux
data.abstract: The Quays of Montreux extend over thirteen kilometers along the shores of Lake Geneva. Here, walkers can admire the exotic flowers and palm trees while also enjoying the breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains.
data.description:
Taking full advantage of the region’s mild microclimate, the city gardeners have enhanced the lakeside with the colours and perfumes of many types of exotic trees and flowers, which have given it a special atmosphere. The plant sculptures are considered to be a special feature of the city. These authentic works of ephemeral art may be viewed from December to May between Clarens and Territet. 

The statue of Freddie Mercury also stands in front of the covered market. This artist lived in Montreux for several years while recording his last album with the group Queen, “Made in Heaven”, in the Mountain Studio, which used to be in the Montreux Casino.

data.name: ViaCook - A pioneering journey across Switzerland
data.abstract: Route: Geneva - Chamonix (F) - Martigny - Leukerbad - Gemmi pass - Bernese Oberland - Lucerne - Rigi - Olten - Neuchâtel - Pontarlier (F)
data.description: What was a novelty for the first group of tourists to visit Switzerland has now become an everyday affair: in 1863, Thomas Cook the excursionist, embarked on his first conducted tour of Switzerland with a group of British tourists. They travelled from Geneva via Chamonix to the Valais district, visited the wonders of the Bernese Oberland, climbed the Rigi and returned to England by train from Lucerne via Neuchâtel. The ViaCook is a tribute to this pioneering journey: on foot, and by boat and train – exactly as in Thomas Cook’s time.

data.name: Parc Aventure des Evaux – High-wire forest adventure
data.abstract: The first tree climbing adventure in Geneva… adrenaline rush and fun guaranteed! Go ape in the trees, right in the heart of the city!
data.description:
Safely supported in your harness, swing from tree to tree through 8 themed courses of varying difficulty designed to delight young and old alike. Platforms, monkey bridges, giant zip wires and other original games will ensure your experience is a memorable one! Plus you can tackle the three longest zip wires in Europe: 160 metres to cross in parallel with your team. 

The park is situated in the Centre sportif des Evaux which offers the perfect location for practising other sports or simply enjoying the fresh air of the forest.

data.name: Liquid pleasure
data.abstract: The caress of the wine. “It’s a pity that you cannot caress the wines,” said the satirist Kurt Tucholsky. He was a great wine lover, as so many Swiss are. It’s a great pleasure to stroll through a vineyard when the vines are budding, or when the grapes are ripening; or to visit winemakers and taste their proudest creations. The largest winegrowing areas are in Western Switzerland, on the shores of Lakes Geneva, Neuchâtel, Biel and Murten, and along the valley of the Rhone in the Valais, Switzerland’s most richly varied winegrowing canton. The Valais is home to the highest commercial vineyards in Europe, but some excellent wines flourish in Eastern Switzerland and Graubünden as well. You may not be able to caress Swiss wines, but they will certainly caress your palate.
data.description:
THE MOST SCENIC: LAKE GENEVA REGION
The setting of the Lavaux vineyards above Lake Geneva is quite simply spectacular. You can taste their wines in the Caveau des Vignerons in Lutry. www.vins-vaudois.com [http://www.vins-vaudois.com] 

THE MOST OF ALL: VALAIS
The Valais is a canton of superlatives: the highest vineyards in Europe (Visperterminen), the highest dry-stone walls in the world (near Sion), and a wine-tasting cellar with 500 local wines (Château de Villa, Sierre). www.vinsduvalais.ch [http://www.vinsduvalais.ch] 

THE MOST SOUTHERN: TICINO
You can explore the vineyards of Ticino in half a day, following the wine trail between Gudo and Biasca – and stop at welcoming grotti (traditional inns) along the way. www.ticino-tourism.ch [http://www.ticino-tourism.ch] 

THE MOST WELCOMING: BÜNDNER HERRSCHAFT
Maienfeld is not only the home of Heidi, but also the home of some of the country’s finest wines. Every weekend from April to November, a different winemaker opens its doors to the public, starting at 11am. www.buendnerweine.ch [http://www.buendnerweine.ch]
ASTONISHING VARIETY, SURPRISING SPECIALITIES
More than 50 grape varieties are cultivated in Switzerland, tempting wine lovers to explore and discover them. To the Valais, to taste the Petite Arvine and Amigne (white), the Humagne rouge and Cornalin (red); to the shores of Lake Geneva, for the rare red Petit Robert; to Lake Zürich, for the white Räuschling; or to the Bündner Herrschaft, where – alongside a magnificent Pinot noir – the age-old Completer grows. You are sure to come across the Chasselas, the main grape of Western Switzerland, as well as the Merlot of Ticino, and maybe even the new Swiss varieties, Garanoir and Diolinoir.

data.name: Place des Nations
data.abstract: The impressive Place des Nations is Geneva’s contribution to world peace. At the heart of international Geneva, this agora provides a forum for global citizens to challenge public opinion and diplomats.
data.description: Located in the extension of the eastern entrance of the Palais des Nations, the Place des Nations is a decidedly contemporary work. On the ground, there is the contrast between the granite of various colours representing the diversity of nations, and the concrete strips that are the traditional building material of Geneva. A dozen water jets of varying heights shoot up directly from the ground. The square is also home to the gigantic "Broken Chair", symbol of the fight against landmines and the fresco of peace, a huge ceramic mosaic created by Swiss artist Hans Erni at the age of 100.

data.name: Shipping to Hermance
data.abstract: Throughout the year, Lake Geneva offers countless opportunities for recreation. Enjoy a relaxing moment on the largest lake in Europe and discover the typical little village of Hermance.
data.description: Leave the Rade (Geneva Bay) behind and discover the beauties of the Geneva lakeside by taking one of the many cruises on the lake. Admire the incomparable view of Mont Blanc, monuments, famous villas, the UN and the parks and gardens around the lake as you peacefully cruise to the village of Hermance. A well-known port of Geneva, this charming medieval town has kept its character of yesteryear with authentic architecture and beautiful old homes.

data.name: English Garden
data.abstract: Planted by the lake in 1854 to visually improve the wooden harbour, this was the first English-style park in Geneva. In the heart of the English Garden, you’ll find the famous Flower Clock, made up of 12,000 kinds of flowers, and the National Monument commemorating Geneva’s integration into the Swiss Confederation.
data.description:
The English Garden is one of the most beautiful places to walk by the lake shore, and one of the liveliest parks in Geneva. Its paths are the perfect place for an idyllic stroll in the centre of the city. In the centre of the park, a giant bronze fountain offers refreshingly cool water to young and old.

Just a few metres from the lake shore is one of Switzerland’s most-photographed attractions: the famous Flower Clock.

Its motifs and floral arrangements change according to the season, to the delight of its visitors. Aside from its decorative value, the Flower Clock is also a symbol of Swiss accuracy, with the time being kept in sync by radio. One more important detail: at a length of 2.5 metres, its second hand is the longest in the world.

data.name: Visit the Vacheron Constantin boutique
data.abstract: Founded in 1755 in Geneva, Vacheron Constantin is the world’s oldest watch manufacturing company with an uninterrupted history spanning more than 250 years.
data.description:
Founders of the very spirit of technical and precious Fine Watchmaking, the men and women at Vacheron Constantin continue designing, developing and producing exceptional timepieces while remaining to the brand’s three fundamentals: expert technique, inspired and harmonious aesthetics and an extremely high level of finishing.
Within the heritage area located on the first floor of the boutique on the Quai de l’Ile, various temporary themed exhibitions, along with ancient machines, tools and workshops, antique furniture and archives, together sum up a quarter-century of horological tradition and provide an educational approach to the brand’s history. Privileged visitors will also enjoy the opportunity of viewing films presenting the famous Métiers d’Art (artistic crafts) that are so dear to Vacheron Constantin.

data.name: Le Petit-Palace
data.abstract: Nestled in the heart of the Old City, Le Petit-Palace is the oldest nightclub in Geneva. The building rests on a section of the wall of the former Geneva.
data.description:
This oldest nightclub in Geneva, nestled in the heart of the Old Town, is located in a building that rests on a section of the wall of the former Geneva. 
Le Petit-Palace, open every evening from 11 pm, is dedicated to your entertainment, and your evening here is sure to be the most memorable of your stay in the city. 
Enjoy the “unique” atmosphere and the warm welcome by the staff. 
Le Petit-Palace offers erotic shows, but remains a nightclub.

address.name: Le Petit-Palace
address.streetAddress: Route de la Tour de Boel 6

data.name: Signal de Bougy: Pré Vert Park
data.abstract: The 110-hectare "Parc Pré Vert du Signal de Bougy" is also ideal for relaxing in verdant surroundings. The location above Lake Geneva between Lausanne and Geneva is perfect for enjoying a hiatus from the daily grind.
data.description:
Not only a minigolf course awaits visitors, the Kid'zland for the little ones, more playgrounds and sports grounds, animals and various diversions for children. There are also an 18-hole golf course, a golf school and a hurdle parcours in the forest. Idyllic ponds, a picnic place and a restaurant with a panorama-terrace, parking spaces, and much more surround all of this. 

The entire complex is open to the public and free for all.

address.name: Parc pré Vert du Signal de Bougy

data.name: Mont Salève
data.abstract: Geneva’s local mountain lies 900 metres above the Jet d’Eau – on French soil but very much part of Geneva’s identity. The mountain has been accessible by rail for over 120 years and offers impressive views over the canton of Geneva to the Jura, and on a clear day to Mont Blanc.
data.description:
From 1887, a steam-powered tram ran directly from Geneva to the foot of the Salève. After 1894, passengers could change there and board the romantic carriages of the electric cog railway that climbed along the rock face to the ridge.

Today, you can take the cable car from Le Pas de l’Echelle (Veyrier) to Mont Salève in just five minutes. From the top, you can enjoy a wonderful panoramic view of the city of Geneva and the Lake Geneva basin with the Jura in the background. To the south-east you can even see the Alps and the Mont Blanc massif.

Hiking trails from the upper station take you to the observatory a further 150 metres up. The Salève is also famous for its many rocky passages, some of which are official hiking trails, others merely paths that are really only suitable for those with a head for heights
INFORMATION

Altitude: 1,097 metres 
How to get there: From Geneva city centre by public bus (no. 8, 34, 41, 44) to Veyrier-Ecole, Veyrier-Douane, Croix-de-Rozon douane, then walk or take the Proxi’Phérique dial-a-ride service to the valley station, cable car to the Salève 
Views: Across the city of Geneva to the Lake Geneva basin, the airport and the Jura, and to the High Alps, Dents du Midi, Aiguille Verte and Mont Blanc 
Attractions: Ridge hike on the Salève, steep descent through the Grotte d’Orjobet (maintained by the SAC), paths for those with a head for heights along the “Balmes” (bands of stone and overhanging rocks). 
Food and drink: L’Horizon du Salève restaurant (next to the upper station) with specialities from Geneva and Savoy 
Accommodation: Geneva and its environs 
Groups: L’Horizon: seating for 135, conference room for 70 people 
Winter: Open, winter hiking, some cross-country skiing on the Salève 
Special comments: Evening trips on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays

data.name: Bastions Park
data.abstract: Parc des Bastions is a wonderful park in the heart of Geneva. Along its shady avenues, you can find some of the city’s most beautiful monuments, including the well-known Reformation Wall. The giant chessboards that are regularly used by the locals will immediately catch your eye.
data.description:
Just below Geneva’s old town in the city centre, Parc des Bastions offers expansive green spaces, giant trees and plenty of fresh air. The park is the site of Geneva’s first botanical garden.

There are a whole host of sights to discover here: The famous Reformation Wall that was built to pay homage to the most important people of the Reformation, the Palais Eynard that is used as a town hall, the library and the University of Geneva.

Behind the giant chess pieces, you’ll also find a popular restaurant and a large adventure playground for children.

data.name: Grand Théâtre
data.abstract: Geneva's Opera, a world renowned institution. A splendid opera house inspired by the architecture of the Parisian Palais Garnier, with top-notch programming for demanding music lovers.
data.description: Geneva’s Opera House is both a venue and an institution. It has the largest stage in French-speaking Switzerland, producing an internationally renowned programme of operas, ballets and recitals every season. Seats 1500.

data.name: The Reformation Wall
data.abstract: Built into the old city walls of Geneva, the Reformation Wall overlooks the Parc des Bastions. Just a stone’s throw from the magnificent Place de Neuve in an exceptionally beautiful setting, the major figures of the Protestant Reformation are depicted as giant statues and bas-reliefs.
data.description: The imposing Reformation Wall stands in the Parc des Bastions, portraying the major figures of the Reformation in the form of huge statues and bas-reliefs. At the centre are John Calvin, William Farel, Théodore de Bèze and John Knox. At the sides are those who spread the Reformation throughout Europe. Engraved in the wall, the motto of Geneva “Post Tenebras Lux” (After darkness, light) is a core phrase of Calvinist philosophy. At the park’s exit lies the Place de Neuve with its buildings dedicated to art and culture.

data.name: Chat Noir
data.abstract: A cultural and friendly space, the Chat Noir has been dedicated to contemporary music since its inception in 1985. Unique in its openness and in the quality of its programming and its role in promoting music, it has become an indispensable part of the music scene in and around Geneva.
data.description:
Legendary scene and essential element in Geneva's cultural life, the Chat Noir is also a bar, a restaurant and nightclub. 
Tiny in size but big in the quality of its programming, this establishment is primarily devoted to the development of emerging artists. 
Eclectic and cosmopolitan, it stops off at the different worlds of modern music, everything from funk to reggae, jazz and French chanson, world music, electronic music…

data.name: Maison Tavel
data.abstract: Maison Tavel is the oldest private dwelling in Geneva and is a unique testimony of medieval civil architecture.
data.description: Maison Tavel is a unique testimony of medieval civil architecture in Switzerland. Destroyed by fire in 1334, it was rebuilt by the Tavel family of the Geneva nobility, which gave the house its character as a fortified mansion and urban palace. After being owned by influential families over subsequent centuries, it was acquired by the City of Geneva in 1963, which then completely restored the building. Transformed into a museum with six levels in 1986, it provides visitors with the opportunity to learn about the urban evolution of the city and various aspects of the past life of its inhabitants.

data.name: Panoramic stroll
data.abstract: Set on a hillside facing Lake Geneva and the mountains, Lausanne offers walkers plenty of extraordinary panoramic views. This downhill stroll will take you to the 10 most beautiful vantage points in the city.
data.description:
Approximately 6 km in length, the panoramic stroll lasts 1h 45mins. It includes the Sauvabelin Tower, the cathedral esplanade, the Signal de Sauvabelin lookout post, the countryside around the Hermitage, the St. Maire Castle esplanade, the Flon footbridge, the vicinity of the Collège du Belvédère, the Esplanade du Montbenon, the Montriond hillcrest and the Languedoc hillside, giving you the chance to discover Lausanne from different perspectives. The walk also passes through the city centre and can be split into sections.

Detailed itinerary and map:
www.lausanne-tourisme.ch [http://www.lausanne-tourisme.ch/en/visit/panoramic-stroll/]

data.name: Mouettes
data.abstract: The Mouettes (seagulls) are the small yellow water taxis that facilitate easy transport around Geneva. Throughout the year, four lines offer return trips linking both banks of Lake Geneva.
data.description: These shuttles are a delight for tourists and locals alike. The former enjoy the harbour crossings while the latter use them as a useful and inexpensive way to commute. This fast and efficient way to cross Lake Geneva makes these little water taxis the pride of Geneva. Public transport tickets are valid on all Mouettes lines. Frequency: every 10 minutes.

data.name: Hot air balloon flights with Alpine panorama
data.abstract: Ready to take off and experience one-of-a-kind views from Switzerland’s highest vantage point? A hot air balloon flight is definitely a memorable adventure and offers the best views over the city of Geneva.
data.description: In addition to unique views, guests aboard the hot air balloon experience moments full of joy and freedom. For over an hour, guests can enjoy the spectacular views of Geneva Lake, the Alps and the Jura, while being gently carried by the wind. Back on solid ground, we raise a toast to this unique experience with champagne. To finish, you will receive a flight diploma and a surprise gift.

data.name: Christmas in Montreux
data.abstract: From the shores of Lake Geneva to the surrounding mountains, Festive Montreux (Montreux Noël) offers a great many activities in conjunction with the traditional Christmas Market.
data.description:
For a whole month the Christmas Market delights the round about 420,000 visitors and offers them a warm and hospitable welcome. 

A visit to the house of the real Father Christmas on the Rocher-de-Naye, a tour of discovery through an authentic Christmas village in Caux, a medieval market and a fairytale festival behind the lofty walls of legendary Chillon Castle: festive Montreux has a lot to offer in addition to the traditional Christmas Market.

More information: Christmas in Montreux [https://www.montreuxnoel.com/en-1-homepage.html]

data.name: Watchmaking workshop
data.abstract: Step into a watchmaker's shoes at a workshop. The Fondation de la Haute Horlogerie (FHH) was established in Geneva in 2005 by three founders: the Richemont Group, Audemars Piguet and Girard Perregaux, to promote fine watchmaking internationally.
data.description: The Foundation has the pleasure to invite you to its watchmaking initiation workshops. Lasting three hours, they allow you to become acquainted with the basics of watchmaking by assembling and dismantling a simple watch mechanism. In the latest of our workshops, the mechanism is decorated. Other than a passion for watches and watchmaking, no skills are required to take part and the workshops are open to all watch and watchmaking enthusiasts, whether amateur or professional. The workshops will take place in the historic salon of Geneva's "Palais de l'Athénée".

data.name: Gourmet panorama trail
data.abstract: Sample Fribourg specialities as you walk along one of the gourmet trails high above Lake Geneva amid the Pre-Alps – this is possible in Les Paccots.
data.description:
Two mountain restaurants and two Alpine huts cater to visitors. At Lac des Joncs, enjoy a farmer's platter with meat and cheese. Then follow the wooden 'Sentier gourmand' signs for almost two hours to sample 'Chalet soup' at the Saletta Alpine hut ... meat stock with milk, cream, four vegetables, macaroni and melted cheese. Your host Raoul Colliard is world famous: at Montreal's 'Festival des lumières' in 2015, he prepared well over 1000 fondues. 

The next gourmet stop is only half an hour’s walk away – Le Vuipay snack bar, where hikers can sample delicious cream macaroni. You’ll then begin a steep descent to discover Les Rosalys restaurant and its “cooked-wine ice cream”, another speciality of Fribourg.

data.name: A delicious discovery tour
data.abstract: Geneva's delicacies are made of far more than just sweet flavours - they hold secrets about the area and its people.
data.description: A region is best discovered through your stomach. This is why those behind Local Flavours, the city tour with a difference, leave no sweet treat unturned! The tour winds in the Old Town of Geneva and all of the best chocolatiers. No tour would be complete without crushing the notorious chocolate cauldron, the “Marmite” - an annual Geneva tradition celebrating the unexpected victory over the Duke of Savoy.

data.name: Vevey – the city of images
data.abstract: Home to the world-renowned School of Photography, the Swiss Camera Museum and the Festival Images Vevey, this city on the shores of Lake Geneva is the photography capital of Switzerland. Vevey hosts Switzerland’s largest open-air visual arts festival every two years.
data.description: The “Festival Images [https://www.images.ch/en/]” is the largest open-air visual arts festival in Switzerland and is held every two years from mid-September to the start of October in Vevey. The festival is free of charge and has rapidly made a name for itself with its enormous reproductions of photographs lining the streets of Vevey. The exhibitions scattered throughout the city provide a key platform for contemporary photography, particularly the photos entered into the international Grand Prix Images Vevey photography competition. Offering one of the highest monetary prizes in Europe, this competition attracts more than 800 projects from all over the world each year.

data.name: Eaux-Vives Park
data.abstract: With its views of Lake Geneva, Parc des Eaux-Vives is probably one of the most beautiful and oldest parks in the city of Geneva. Nature lovers will appreciate the many hundred-year-old trees and the expansive lawned areas. Plage des Eaux-Vives (Eaux-Vives Beach) is also just a stone’s throw away.
data.description:
Eaux-Vives Park, dating back to the 16th century, is the natural continuation of Parc de la Grange, which is accessible through a gate. The manor house dominating the park is a well-respected hotel and restaurant, and a perfect spot to fortify yourself alongside captivating views of the lake and the Jura mountains.

Eaux-Vives Beach was built to respond to social trends and upgrade the urban centre. The public facility with a 400-metre-long sandy beach is just a ten-minute walk from the centre, includes a water garden with rare plants and a park. The new haven of calm also includes a large esplanade for dinghies, a fishing village and a restaurant facing Geneva’s famous fountain, the Jet d’Eau.

data.name: Vaudoise Farm
data.abstract: The true treasures of the Lake Geneva Region are wine, cheese and other fine food products: most are available at these taste-tempting shops.
data.description: Discover the true wealth of the Vaud region! Wines, cheeses and regional products are all available at the Vaudoise Farm, and many products may even be tasted: fruit, vegetables, smoked meats, products direct from around seventy producers who supply each shop. The production methods are used openly and respect the environment.

data.name: Photo Spot The Port of Morges
data.abstract: The picturesque Morges region stretches along vineyards between Lake Geneva and the Jura forests. During the 17th century, Morges, with its unique guard houses known as ‘guérites’, was the most important commercial port on Lake Geneva. The castle, with its striking towers, houses five museums and, on a clear day, the glistening, snow-capped peaks of the breathtaking Mont Blanc massif can be seen. From April to October, a plethora of flowers in the most beautiful colours adorns the city.

data.name: Fish your dish – catch your dinner
data.abstract: Each day, Patrice goes out on Lake Geneva to catch fresh fish. He works at the five-star hotel Les Trois Couronnes and knows the Swiss Riviera like no other.
data.description: With a little luck, it is not long before a fish is on the line or in the net. To pass the time – or simply cool off in the hot summer months – nothing beats a dip in the glorious fresh water. If the trip was successful, the Michelin Star chef Cécile Fontannaz prepares the catch under the watchful eyes of his guests in the evening.

price.description: CHF 150.00 per guide CHF 50.00 incl. food

data.name: Vernex Park
data.abstract: The Vernex Park is set on the shores of Lake Geneva next to the Auditorium Stravinsky and offers walkers a green area along the extension of the flourishing quays of the Montreux Riviera. Each July, one of the stages for the Montreux Jazz Festival is set up in this park.
data.description: Between its large, century-old trees and its majestic magnolias, the Vernex Park is home to several works of art, including the fountain "in memory of Vibeke" by Jean Flemming Soerensen and the Montrailes sculpture by Antoine Poncet. At one end of the park, busts of Richard Strauss and Miles Davis by Bernard Bavaud face each other, reminding visitors of the Montreux Riviera’s magnificent past. On the other side, the playground and slightly sloping lawn ensure that the Vernex Park remains a popular meeting place for families and for walkers seeking tranquility.

data.name: Gaze over the Lavaux on a paddleboard
data.description: Sophie Durant has always lived at Lake Geneva and has got to know the area well from the water too. Her guided half or full-day paddleboard excursions take the group past Montreux, Clarens und Vevey. This is a chance to see the small towns from a different perspective. A walk through the picturesque Lavaux can be combined with a tasting at a local vineyard.

data.name: Chocolate tour in Lavaux
data.abstract: An unusual way to enjoy chocolate: as they hike through the Lavaux area, guests learn more about the history of everyone’s favourite sweet temptation and savour the delights of Grand Cru pralines.
data.description: An experienced chocolatier reveals the aromatic richness of the finest cocoa beans during a tour of the breathtaking natural scenery of Lake Geneva, inviting guests to immerse themselves in the world of chocolate. Naturally there are also plenty of opportunities to taste the products themselves.

data.name: La Grange Park
data.abstract: The La Grange Park sits right next to the Eaux-Vives Park and offers a unique view of the lake basin. The wonderful flower garden stretches out over 12,000 square metres and delights its guests with more than 200 varieties of roses.
data.description:
The park is the legacy of the Favre family in Geneva, who gifted it to the city in 1918. It is connected to the neighbouring Eaux-Vives Park via a gate at the end of each of the parks. A manor house with fountains and beautiful flower gardens dominates the park.

The highlight nowadays is the rose garden, which was laid out in 1945/46 according to the plans of Armand Auberson. These had the geometric lines returning back to the landscape park. In a large octagon, you can find around 200 varieties of roses. At the annual “Concours international de roses nouvelles” (international competition for new roses), rose growers from all over the world present their new varieties.

data.name: Cinémathèque suisse
data.abstract: Cinémathèque suisse (Switzerland’s film archive) can be viewed as Switzerland’s museum of film. But it’s not solely concerned with Swiss films, instead everything concerning the art of filming and audio-visual media in Switzerland.
data.description:
The Cinémathèque suisse collection is made up of 70,000 film copies, 2.8 million photos and 300,000 posters – and ranks sixth according to the international association of film archives (FIAF) where the world’s most important photo archives are concerned. Besides entertaining and documentary films, the Cinémathèque Suisse collection includes archived documents from Swiss film weeks, advertising and job films, as well as amateur films. In fact, you could well say that Cinémathèque is Switzerland’s audio-visual memory bank. 

As with all other comparable institutions worldwide, Cinémathèque Suisse collects everything associated with film development in Switzerland. The collection is therefore not limited solely to productions shot within home borders, instead includes films of all origins and formats. 

Cinémathèque suisse generally organizes three film presentations in a day. These take place in the Cinématographe and Paderewski hall of the Casino de Montbenon. Special events, premiers and gala evenings are mostly held in the Capitole; Switzerland’s largest cinema hall, which the town of Lausanne makes available to Cinémathèque suisse since 2010. 

Certain presentations in connection with Cinémathèque suisse are also viewed in the cinema halls of other towns, namely Filmpodium in Zurich and the Cinéma du Grütli in Geneva.

data.name: The Wine School
data.abstract: Do you want to know more about wine? Or present someone with a special treat such as an invitation to a wine seminar?
data.description:
The wine school of Geneva-Lausanne-Evian was founded a long time ago. Every year new ideas are incorporated. Here are some examples:

 * Private tasting: Experts will advise you in their homes, while you taste a variety of regional wines.
 * Wine tasting for groups: Invite a few friends for an evening of wine tasting at the Wine School.
 * Dinner, including wine tasting at the Wine School.
 * Animations/events, ideas for a company celebration, wedding, birthday, etc.
 * Exceptional gifts.
 * Professional training courses.
 * Various consultations by experts.

data.name: Perle du Lac Park and Botanical Garden
data.abstract: With its magical view of Mont-Blanc across the lake, Perle du Lac Park is the ideal place for relaxing moments spent by the lakeside. It’s no wonder that the wife of Rolex founder Hans Wilsdorf called this place the “pearl of the lake”.
data.description:
From Perle du Lac Park, it’s not far to the botanical garden by the lake shore. There, you’ll also find the little harbour with the jetty for the “mouettes genevoises” (ferries) linking the two sides of the lake. The park is an extension of Mon Repos and Moynier Park, with a marvellous view of the lake.

On the grounds of Geneva’s botanical gardens, spread over 28 hectares and showcasing more than 12,000 kinds of plants and trees, you’ll find the kind of peace and quiet that invites you to meditate and reflect. The 21-metre-high neoclassical greenhouse reminiscent of a miniature palace is particularly striking. This is home to plants requiring Mediterranean climate conditions from all over the world, such as succulents or gigantic palms, whose leaves reach all the way to the dome. With its six million samples, the garden’s herbarium is one of the largest in the world.

data.name: Rue du Rhône
data.abstract: Makes the eyes sparkle! The Rue du Rhône is the luxury shoppers’ paradise where the most prestigious brands vie with one another in elegance and style. The biggest names in the worlds of watchmaking, jewellery and fashion all converge here. You'll need at least half a day to resist this bevy of temptations!
data.description: Shopping addicts will find all their dreams come true at the Rue du Rhône! Here, the major retailers are dedicated to fulfilling all your longings for luxury. Featuring watches, fashion and jewellery, and visits to the boutiques of the master chocolatiers, this tour lets you discover (or rediscover) the brands that have given Geneva its reputation. Nowhere else will you find such a concentration of prestige.

data.name: Introductory course in watchmaking
data.abstract: Discover the fascinating art of mechanical watchmaking in the Initium watchmaker's workshop. Using a screwdriver and tweezers, watch lovers can try for themselves and assemble a clockwork with great finesse and dexterity.
data.description: Geneva is the international capital of the art of luxury watchmaking. Where else, if not here, can visitors learn about watchmaking? The Initium [https://www.initium.ch/ ] workshop offers a variety of introductory courses, creating a unique experience that you are sure to remember. Under the expert guidance of talented watchmakers, visitors learn the different steps of watchmaking. This also includes precision work such as engraving or timing adjustment.

data.name: La Garenne educational tour
data.abstract: Discover the excellent standards of private education in Switzerland with a professional presentation and a visit to an international school.
data.description:
Explore and become familiar with the Swiss system of private schooling. The two-hour programme includes a 45-minute presentation about international education in Switzerland and a 30-minute tour of the school, in which you will be introduced to the high standards and excellence of private education in Switzerland. The visit will end with a light buffet and time to network with teachers and students, helping you to further understand the international education experience. 

Available in Villars (Alps of Lake Geneva Region), in picturesque settings that epitomise the beauty of Switzerland and which contribute to a productive academic study environment.

data.name: Basse-Ruche adventure park
data.abstract: A relaxing game on the Bass-Ruche swin-golf course!
data.description: In summer, the Basse-Ruche region has more to offer than just glorious views of Lake Geneva and the Alps. Other features include a family swin-golf course, grass-boarding, grass scooters, archery and crossbow lessons. There is still plenty to do in winter, however: cross-country skiing by night, alpine skiing, bobsled lifts and snowshoe trails. Find refreshments in the only restaurant in the Alps that is accessible by car all year round! On the menu you will find fondues, fried tomme, cheese, raclette and grilled meats.

data.name: Moléson – a popular destination in the Fribourg Pre-Alps
data.abstract: It’s no wonder that the Moléson has a special place in the hearts of Fribourg’s citizens: the journey up to the panoramic peak is an adventure in itself. Once you reach the summit, you are greeted by wonderful 360° panoramic views of the Gruyère Pre-Alps and the Bernese and Valais Alps.
data.description:
The Gruyère region is known not only for the small town of Gruyères [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/reiseziele/gruyeres-greyerz/] and the world-famous cheese that bears its name, but also for the Moléson mountain, which can be seen from miles around. Two modern cable cars with panoramic windows connect the village of Moléson-sur-Gruyères [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/reiseziele/moleson-sur-gruyeres/] with the Pre-Alpine peak. When you arrive at 2,002 metres above sea level, the whole of western Switzerland is at your feet: from Lake Geneva to the famous peaks of the Bernese Oberland, from Mont Blanc and the Jura to the Three Lakes region.

In addition to the magnificent panorama, a visit to Moléson is particularly worthwhile because of the wide range of leisure activities on offer:

SUMMER
In summer, adventurers can experience the thrill of a rapid ride down the summer toboggan run or try their skills in a downhill cart. A host of hiking trails invite visitors to explore the area on foot. Those with a head for heights can attempt one of the two via ferrata routes or enjoy the spectacular views on the Trematta ridge hike [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/erlebnisse/route/sentier-de-la-crete-du-moleson/]. The demonstration cheese dairy [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/moleson-alpine-cheese-dairy/]is well worth a visit, where you can learn what life was like for the cowherds in days gone by. Every day at 10 a.m. (May to September), the cheesemaker lifts his cheese from the copper vat and talks about his work.

WINTER
In winter, the Moléson is a paradise for tobogganers, skiers and snowboarders. There is also plenty on offer for ski tourers and freeriders.

Tip: If you’re staying in Moléson, the Passe-Moléson [https://www.moleson.ch/en/passe-moleson/] is well worth getting. This all-inclusive pass covers cable cars, the toboggan run, downhill carts and much more besides!



Altitude 2,002m Getting there Train from Bulle or Montbovon to Gruyères, bus to Moléson-sur-Gruyères, funicular to Plan-Francey and cable car to the Moléson summit Opening hours The opening hours [https://www.moleson.ch/horaires/]of the funicular and gondola vary depending on the season and assume good weather conditions.
Magic Pass The Magic Pass [https://www.magicpass.ch/en/] is valid for the funicular and the gondola.
Food and drink The Le Sommet summit restaurant serves typical Gruyère specialities such as fondue moitié-moitié (half Gruyère, half Vacherin) or meringues with double cream Accommodation Accommodation options in Moléson [https://www.fribourgregion.ch/en/la-gruyere/alpine-huts/?r=7408&attr_58=1] Groups Theatre/conference hall in Moléson-sur-Gruyères: 120 people Special comments Saturdays and Sundays evening trips from 6 p.m. until 11 p.m. to Le Sommet upper station and back down to Moléson-sur-Gruyères (summer season). Evening trips are available in winter to Plan-Francey middle station and back down to Moléson-sur-Gruyères.
